p.s: Moorella (Moo.rel'la. N. L. fem. n. Moorella, in honor of W. E. C. Moore, an American bacteriologist)
Cells are rod shaped and occur singly, in pairs, or in chains.
Cells are generally gram positive, although older cultures may stain gram negative.
Spores are round to slightly oval and terminal or subterminal and distend the cells.
The optimum temperature for growth is 56 to 60°C, and the maximum temperature for growth is 65 to 68°C.
Homoacetogenic, growing chemolithotrophically with H2 and CO2 or CO, as well as chemoorganotrophically with some carbohydrates or methanol, producing acetate.
Produces a variety of electron carriers, including cytochrome b and menaquinone MK-7.
The cell walls contain LL-diaminopimelic acid and glycine.
The G+C content of the DNA is 53 to 55 mol%.
The type species is Moorella thermoacetica.
